description: From Medieval Latin indīviduālis, from Latin indīviduum (“an indivisible thing”), neuter of indīviduus (“indivisible, undivided”), from in + dīviduus (“divisible”), from dīvidō (“divide”).

adjectives.description: individual (comparative more individual, superlative most individual)

entries.meaning: Relating to a single person or thing as opposed to more than one.
examples: As we can't print them all together, the individual pages will have to be printed one by one.

entries.meaning: Intended for a single person as opposed to more than one person.
examples: individual personal pension; individual cream cakes

entries.meaning: Not divisible without losing its identity.
A person considered alone, rather than as belonging to a group of people.
(law) A single physical human being as a legal subject, as opposed to a legal person such as a corporation.
examples: Every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right to the equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination […].

entries.meaning: An object, be it a thing or an agent, as contrasted to a class.
(statistics) An element belonging to a population.
